comment._content: Just going on the building activity at Garden Island (zoom in on the purl version), I'd say that this pic dates from 1887-1888... looking at this pic... www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363491416/ ...and keeping in mind Beachcomber's notes/links etc...note how in the above pic, the lone tree on the Garden Island hump has gone...plus in the above pic, the construction of the barracks appears to have advanced...but isn't yet completed...which maybe suggests an 1887/1888 date. Just for interest, this later pic shows how Garden Island looked a few years later - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2376052141/ I'll leave my other long-way-round notes here for possible interest...future reference...insomnia remedy, etc The Norwich Union building (aka Norwich Chambers) was located at the corner of Hunter and Bligh Sts...per this SMH item, the basement of the new building was being excavated in August 1885 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13595372 ...construction appears to have been completed by mid-late 1886...various digitised newspaper hits indicate that tenants had moved in by September 1886...the Norwich Union building also features in this pic - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2697490952/ ; the row to the left of the Norwich Union building appears to have still been there in 1898-1899...see the Sydney Mail item I've linked to at this pic - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3004411840/ Bowden's Clubhouse Hotel...was located at the corner of Hunter and Castlereagh Sts...the lease evidently expired in January 1889 (notice bottom of column 4) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13690225 ...after which Bowden shifted stumps to the corner of Hunter and Elizabeth Sts - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71115146 ...from what I can establish, the hotel at the corner of Hunter and Castlereagh Sts then became known as the Club House Hotel...Bowden's new hotel at the corner of Hunter and Elizabeth Sts appears to have been known as Bowden's Hotel...Joseph Boden, the proprietor, died in July 1889...in this pic I gather we're looking at Bowden's Clubhouse Hotel at the corner of Hunter & Castlereagh Sts...though I suspect the sign we see here might have been on the wall of the building next door... Carington Chambers (spelt thus) is a bit of a puzzle...going on various digitised newspaper hits, there was a Carrington Chambers at ?30-32 (or 30 and 32) Castlereagh St until ca. May 1889...but there also appears to have been a Carrington Chambers at 6 Castlereagh St...it's not entirely clear whether the building name was transferred from 30-32 Castlereagh St to 6 Castlereagh St, but just going on modern street numbering and Google Maps, the 'Carington Chambers' we see in this pic looks like it might have been at 6 Castlereagh St rather than at 30-32 Castlereagh St... Hawkes & Co advertised themselves as 'successors to Buchan Thomson'...they ran a coaching, livery and horse hire business...they appear to have moved to new premises in the Tattersall's Building at the corner of Castlereagh & Hunter Sts in ca. April 1883 (2nd notice, column 2) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70998784 also see their advert here - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70967599 ... Hawkes & Co appear to have operated at the Tattersall's Building until early 1888, when they drop off the radar...the proprietor died in 1884 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13562348 ...and I've encountered one notice which indicates that the business was subsequently run by trustees...possibly until ca. 1888...I'd say that in this pic we see the Tattersall's building at the corner of Castlereagh & Hunter Sts, during the period Hawkes & Co were there, ie. 1883 to ca.1888...
